question:
Given below a statement followed by 2 inferences. Choose the inference that can be inferred from the given statement by selecting the right option.

Statement: Due to the rapid increase in the pandemic most of the states are locked down.

Inferences:

I. The pandemic is dangerous.

II. The pandemic will spread rapidly.
option_1: Both inferences I and II follow
option_2: Neither inference I nor inference II follows
option_3: Only inference I follows
option_4: Only inference II follows
solution:
• Inference I: "The pandemic is dangerous."
    • Since most states are locking down due to the pandemic's rapid increase, it implies that the situation is severe and poses a risk.
    • Governments typically impose lockdowns when a threat is significant, making this inference valid.
  • Inference II: "The pandemic will spread rapidly."
    • The statement mentions that the pandemic is increasing rapidly, which suggests a fast spread.
    • While it doesn't explicitly predict future trends, the existing rapid increase implies a likelihood of continued spread.
    • Therefore, this inference is also reasonable.

Correct Answer: Both inferences I and II follow.

question:
Given below a statement followed by 2 inferences. Choose the inference that can be inferred from the given statement by selecting the right option.

Statement: Out of 20 students in a class, 15 passed in English and 18 passed in mathematics.

Inferences:

I. There are few students who passed in both the subjects.

II. No student failed in both the subjects.
option_1: Both inferences I and II follow
option_2: Only inference I follows
option_3: Only inference II follows
option_4: Neither inference I nor inference II follows
solution:
Inference I: There are few students who passed in both the subjects.

Follows –
If 15 passed English and 18 passed Math, the total pass count is 33.
Since there are only 20 students, some must have passed both subjects to account for the overlap.

Inference II: No student failed in both the subjects.

Does not follow –
The statement doesn't tell us about students who failed both.
There could still be students outside both groups.
So, this cannot be definitely concluded.

question:
Given below a statement followed by 2 inferences. Choose the inference that can be inferred from the given statement by selecting the right option.

Statement: The market share of the mobile company "X" has increased from 3% to 9% from the year 2018 to 2019 and more mobiles are sold overall in the year 2019.

Inferences:

I. Mobile company X has sold more mobiles in the year 2019 as compared to 2018.

II. The sales of mobile company X is tripled from the year 2018 to 2019.
option_1: Neither inference I nor inference II follows
option_2: Both inferences I and II follow
option_3: Only inference I follows
option_4: Only inference II follows
solution:
Inference I: Company X sold more mobiles in 2019 than in 2018.

Follows – Market share increased, and overall mobile sales also increased. So, even the actual number of mobiles sold by X must have increased.

Inference II: Company X’s sales tripled from 2018 to 2019.

Does not follow – The market shares tripled (3% to 9%), but this doesn't guarantee that actual sales tripled.
For example, the total market size also changed.

Correct Answer: Only inference I follows.

question:
Given below a statement followed by 2 inferences. Choose the inference that can be inferred from the given statement by selecting the right option.

Statement: A mango farm has 100 trees and the average mango production from each tree is 1200.

Inferences:

I. There is no mango tree whose mango production is less than 1200.

II. Mango farming is more beneficial than any other kind of farming.
option_1: Neither inference I nor inference II follows
option_2: Both inferences I and II follow
option_3: Only inference II follows
option_4: Only inference I follows
solution:
Inference I: There is no mango tree whose mango production is less than 1200.

follow –
An average of 1200 means some trees could produce more, and some less.
So it's possible some trees produced fewer than 1200 mangoes.

Inference II: Mango farming is more beneficial than any other kind of farming.

Does not follow –
The statement only gives data about one mango farm, with no comparison to other kinds of farming.
So this is just an assumption, not a valid inference.

Correct Answer: Only inference I follows.

question:
Assuming the given statement to be true, select inference as one of the options.

Statement: Alexa goes to the market every alternate day and she went to the market yesterday.

Inference: She goes to the market 4 times a week.
option_1: Irrelevant
option_2: Uncertain
option_3: True
option_4: False
solution:
Explanation:

  • "Every alternate day" means she visits the market once every 2 days.
  • In a 7-day week, starting from the day she went (say, Monday), her visits would be:
    Monday, Wednesday, Friday, Sunday → 4 times in 7 days.
  • This always results in 4 visits per week, no matter which day she starts from, due to the 2-day interval fitting evenly into 7.

So, the inference is logically correct based on the statement.

Correct Answer: True

question:
Given below a statement followed by 2 inferences. Choose the inference that can be inferred from the given statement by selecting the right option.

Statement: More than 95% of the people working in "Tel Aviv" know martial art.

Inferences:

I. 5% of the people working in "Tel Aviv" know something other than martial art.

II. Less than 5% of the people working in "Tel Aviv" don't know martial art.
option_1: Only inference I follows
option_2: Only inference II follows
option_3: Neither inference I nor inference II follows
option_4: Both inferences I and II follow
solution:
Inference I:

5% of the people working in Tel Aviv know something other than martial art.
Does not follow –
We don’t know what the remaining <5% know.
They might know nothing, or something else. The statement only talks about knowing martial art, not other skills.

Inference II:

Less than 5% of the people working in Tel Aviv don't know martial art.
Follows –
If more than 95% know martial art, then less than 5% logically do not.
This is a direct inference from the statement.

Correct Answer: Only inference II follows.

question:
In the question below a statement is given followed by two conclusions, I and II. You have to consider the statement to be true, even if it seems to be at variance from commonly known facts. You are to decide which of the given conclusions is drawn from the given statement.

Statements—In case of outstanding candidates, the condition of previous experience of social work may be waived by the Admission Committee for M.A. (Social work).

Conclusions—

I. Some of the students for M.A. (Social Work) will have previous experience of social work.

II. Some of the students for M.A. (Social Work) will not have previous experience of social work.
option_1: If only conclusion I follows
option_2: If only conclusion II follows,
option_3: If both I and II follows.
option_4: If neither I nor II follows.
solution:
The statement suggests that previous experience in social work is a condition for admission, but in the case of outstanding candidates, it may be waived. This implies that:

  • Some students will have previous experience (since it's generally required).
  • Some students may not have previous experience (if the condition is waived for them).

Thus, both conclusions I and II follow, making the correct answer: "If both I and II follow."

question:
In the question below a statement is given followed by two conclusions, I and II. You have to consider the statement to be true, even if it seems to be at variance from commonly known facts. You are to decide which of the given conclusions is drawn from the given statement.

Statements—Company X has marketed the product, go ahead to purchase if its price and quality are in your consideration.

Conclusions—

I. The product must be good in quality.

II. The price of the product must be reasonable.
option_1: If only conclusion I follows
option_2: If only conclusion II follows,
option_3: If both I and II follows.
option_4: If neither I nor II follows.
solution:
Conclusion I: The product must be good in quality.

Follows — because the recommendation is made if you consider quality, implying it is acceptable or good.

Conclusion II: The price of the product must be reasonable.

Follows — because the suggestion is made if price is a factor, implying it is reasonably priced.

Final Answer (if interpreted this way):

Both I and II follow.

question:
In the question below a statement is given followed by two conclusions, I and II. You have to consider the statement to be true, even if it seems to be at variance from commonly known facts. You are to decide which of the given conclusions is drawn from the given statement.

Vegetables prices are soaring in the market.

Conclusions—

I. Vegetables are becoming a rare commodity.

II. People cannot eat vegetables.
option_1: If only conclusion I follows
option_2: If only conclusion II follows,
option_3: If both I and II follows.
option_4: If neither I nor II follows.
solution:
Conclusion I: Vegetables are becoming a rare commodity.

  • Rising prices could be due to many reasons—not just rarity.
  • The statement doesn’t confirm that vegetables are rare.
  • It does not follow.

Conclusion II: People cannot eat vegetables.

  • The statement doesn’t say anything about people being unable to eat vegetables.
  • Higher prices don’t automatically mean total inaccessibility.
  • It does not follow.

Correct Answer:

If neither I nor II follows.

question:
In the question below a statement is given followed by two conclusions, I and II. You have to consider the statement to be true, even if it seems to be at variance from commonly known facts. You are to decide which of the given conclusions is drawn from the given statement.

Statements—This world is neither good nor evil, each man manufactures a world for himself.

Conclusions—

I. Some people find this world quite good.

II. Some people find this world quite bad.
option_1: If only conclusion I follows
option_2: If only conclusion II follows,
option_3: If both I and II follows.
option_4: If neither I nor II follows.
solution:
Conclusion I: Some people find this world quite good.

Follows — since people create their own view of the world, some may see it as good.

Conclusion II: Some people find this world quite bad.

Also follows — by the same reasoning, others may perceive the world as bad.

Correct Answer:

If both I and II follow.

question:
In the question below a statement is given followed by two conclusions, I and II. You have to consider the statement to be true, even if it seems to be at variance from commonly known facts. You are to decide which of the given conclusions is drawn from the given statement.

Statements—Today out of the world population of several thousand millions the majority of men have to live under Governments which refuse them personal liberty and the right of dissent.

Conclusions—

I. People are indifferent to personal liberty and right to dissent.

II. People desire personal liberty and right to dissent.
option_1: If only conclusion I follows
option_2: If only conclusion II follows,
option_3: If both I and II follows.
option_4: If neither I nor II follows.
solution:
Conclusion I: People are indifferent to personal liberty and right to dissent.

  • This clearly does not follow.
  • The statement never suggests indifference; in fact, being denied a right may imply it matters.
  • So, Conclusion I is rejected.

Conclusion II: People desire personal liberty and right to dissent.

  • While not explicitly stated, this conclusion can be reasonably inferred.
  • The fact that the statement highlights the denial of these rights suggests they are valuable and that people would naturally desire them.
  • In many reasoning questions, such conclusions are allowed if they align with the intent and implication of the statement.

Final Answer:

If only conclusion II follows.

question:
In the question below a statement is given followed by two conclusions, I and II. You have to consider the statement to be true, even if it seems to be at variance from commonly known facts. You are to decide which of the given conclusions is drawn from the given statement.

Statements—In diabetes, there is an excess of sugar in the body. Our body needs sugar for energy, the quantity of sugar in excess of body’s requirement is excreted through urine.

Conclusions—

I. The excessive consumption of sugar is likely to lead to diabetes.

II. Consumption of sugar should be avoided.
option_1: If only conclusion I follows
option_2: If only conclusion II follows,
option_3: If both I and II follows.
option_4: If neither I nor II follows.
solution:
Conclusion I: The excessive consumption of sugar is likely to lead to diabetes.

Follows logically —

  • The statement links excess sugar in the body to diabetes.
  • While it doesn't directly say "excessive consumption causes diabetes," it's a reasonable inference that consuming more sugar than needed can lead to excess sugar in the body — and thus may cause diabetes.

Conclusion II: Consumption of sugar should be avoided.

Does not follow —

  • The statement does not advise against sugar altogether.
  • In fact, it says sugar is needed for energy, so avoiding it completely is not supported by the statement.

Final Answer:

If only conclusion I follows.

question:
In the question below a statement is given followed by two conclusions, I and II. You have to consider the statement to be true, even if it seems to be at variance from commonly known facts. You are to decide which of the given conclusions is drawn from the given statement.

Statements—Until your country achieves economic equality, political freedom and democracy would be meaningless.

Conclusions—

I. Political freedom and democracy go hand in hand.

II. Economic equality leads to real political freedom and democracy.
option_1: If only conclusion I follows
option_2: If only conclusion II follows,
option_3: If both I and II follows.
option_4: If neither I nor II follows.
solution:
Conclusion I: Political freedom and democracy go hand in hand.

  • The statement does not explicitly say that political freedom and democracy always exist together.
  • It only talks about their meaning being tied to economic equality.
  • So, Conclusion I does not necessarily follow.

Conclusion II: Economic equality leads to real political freedom and democracy.

  • The statement clearly implies that without economic equality, political freedom and democracy lack meaning.
  • This suggests that achieving economic equality is essential to having real political freedom and democracy.
  • So, Conclusion II follows.

Final Answer:

If only conclusion II follows.

question:
In the question below a statement is given followed by two conclusions, I and II. You have to consider the statement to be true, even if it seems to be at variance from commonly known facts. You are to decide which of the given conclusions is drawn from the given statement.

Statements—Water supply in wards A and B of the city will be affected about 50% on Friday because repairing work of main lines is to be carried out.

Conclusions—

I. The residents in these wards should economise on water on Friday.

II. These residents in these wards should store some water on the previous day.
option_1: If only conclusion I follows
option_2: If only conclusion II follows,
option_3: If both I and II follows.
option_4: If neither I nor II follows.
solution:
Conclusion I:

Residents should economize on water on Friday.

  • Since water supply will be reduced, it is reasonable to use water carefully on that day.
  • Conclusion I follows.

Conclusion II:

Residents should store some water on the previous day.

  • Knowing the supply will be affected, it’s logical to store water in advance to avoid shortage.
  • Conclusion II also follows.

Final Answer:

If both I and II follow.

question:
Statements—The government of country X has recently announced several concessions and offered attractive package tours for foreign visitors.

Conclusions—

I. Now, more number of foreign tourists will visit the country.

II. The government of country X seems to be serious in attracting tourists.
option_1: If only conclusion I follows
option_2: If only conclusion II follows,
option_3: If both I and II follows.
option_4: If neither I nor II follows.
solution:
Conclusion I:

Now, more number of foreign tourists will visit the country.

  • Since the government is offering concessions and attractive packages, it is reasonable to expect that tourist arrivals will increase.
  • The statement implies an intention that usually leads to more visitors.

Conclusion II:

The government of country X seems to be serious in attracting tourists.

  • The announcement of concessions and packages clearly shows the government’s seriousness.

Final Answer:

If both I and II follow.

question:
In the question, a statement is given, followed by two arguments, I and II. You have to consider the statement to be true even it seems to be at variance from commonly known facts. You have to decide which of the given arguments, if any, is a strong argument.

Statement—Government should stop spending huge amounts of money on international sports.

Arguments—

I. Yes, this money can be utilised for upliftment of the poor.

II. No, sport persons will be frustrated and will not get international exposure.
option_1: if only argument I is strong
option_2: if only argument II is strong
option_3: if neither I nor II is strong
option_4: if both I & II are strong.
solution:
Conclusion I:

This money can be better used for upliftment of the poor.

  • Although reasonable, this conclusion is an opinion about alternative use of funds, not a direct consequence of the statement.
  • It’s a weaker argument here because the statement only mentions stopping spending, not what should be done instead.
  • So, Conclusion I does not strongly follow.

Conclusion II:

Sportspersons will be frustrated and will not get international exposure.

  • This is a direct consequence of stopping spending on international sports.
  • It logically follows that if funding stops, athletes lose opportunities and exposure.
  • So, Conclusion II follows strongly.

Final Answer:

If only conclusion II follows.

question:
In the question, a statement is given, followed by two arguments, I and II. You have to consider the statement to be true even it seems to be at variance from commonly known facts. You have to decide which of the given arguments, if any, is a strong argument.

Statement—Should there be only one type of schools up to matriculation in the entire country?

Arguments—

I. Yes, this exists in some of the western countries.

II. No, schools in rural and urban areas need to be different.
option_1: if only argument I is strong
option_2: if only argument II is strong
option_3: if neither I nor II is strong
option_4: if both I & II are strong.
solution:
Argument I:

Yes, this exists in some western countries.

  • Simply stating something exists elsewhere doesn’t address whether it’s suitable or beneficial here.
  • It’s more of a factual observation than a strong argument for the question.

Argument II:

No, schools in rural and urban areas need to be different.

  • While this sounds reasonable, it’s an opinion and not necessarily a strong argument because it assumes differences that may be addressed by a unified system.
  • It does not conclusively prove why there should or shouldn’t be one type of school.

Final Answer:

If neither I nor II is strong.

question:
In the question, a statement is given, followed by two arguments, I and II. You have to consider the statement to be true even it seems to be at variance from commonly known facts. You have to decide which of the given arguments, if any, is a strong argument.

Statement—Should there be a complete ban on use of chemical pesticides in the agricultural fields?

Arguments—

I. No, the crops will get damaged by the pests as almost each crop is attacked by pests during its life cycle.

II. Yes, this pollutes environment and also contaminates ground water, instead biological pesticides should be used.
option_1: if only argument I is strong
option_2: if only argument II is strong
option_3: if neither I nor II is strong
option_4: if both I & II are strong.
solution:
Argument I:

No, the crops will get damaged by pests as almost each crop is attacked by pests during its life cycle.

  • This is a strong argument because it highlights the practical need to control pests to protect crops and ensure food production.

Argument II:

Yes, this pollutes environment and contaminates groundwater; instead biological pesticides should be used.

  • This is also a strong argument since it points out the environmental and health hazards of chemical pesticides and suggests a safer alternative.

Final Answer:

If both I & II are strong.

question:
In the question, a statement is given, followed by two arguments, I and II. You have to consider the statement to be true even it seems to be at variance from commonly known facts. You have to decide which of the given arguments, if any, is a strong argument.

Statement—Should the tuition fees in all schools—both Govt. aided and unaided up to class X be completely waived for all children?

Arguments—

I. Yes, this will improve the literacy rate in our country.

II. No, particularly the unaided schools should be allowed to charge tuition fees to meet the regular expenses.
option_1: if only argument I is strong
option_2: if only argument II is strong
option_3: if either I or II is strong
option_4: if both I & II are strong.
solution:
Argument I:

Yes, this will improve the literacy rate in our country.

  • This is a strong argument because free education can increase access and literacy.

Argument II:

No, unaided schools should charge fees to meet expenses.

  • This is also a strong argument for the financial viability of unaided schools.

Why “either I or II” and not “both”?

Sometimes, the arguments contradict each other — if you accept one, the other weakens. So only one argument can be considered strong at a time depending on the perspective you take.

Final Answer:

If either I or II is strong.

question:
In the question, a statement is given, followed by two arguments, I and II. You have to consider the statement to be true even it seems to be at variance from commonly known facts. You have to decide which of the given arguments, if any, is a strong argument.

Statement: ShouldIndiastopexploring presence of hydrocarbons in both onshore and offshore locations?

Arguments:

I. Yes, this leads to wastage of precious resources as the hydrocarbon reserves are scanty.

II. No, we must try to become less dependent on foreign countries for our energy needs by exploring all possibilities.
option_1: if only argument I is strong
option_2: if only argument II is strong
option_3: if either I or II is strong
option_4: if both I & II are strong.
solution:
Argument I:

Yes, this leads to wastage of precious resources as the hydrocarbon reserves are scanty.

  • This is a strong argument because if reserves are very limited, further exploration might be inefficient or wasteful.

Argument II:

No, we must try to become less dependent on foreign countries for energy by exploring all possibilities.

  • This is also a strong argument because reducing energy dependence is crucial for national security and self-reliance.

Why either I or II?

  • These arguments contradict each other: if you accept one, the other weakens.
  • Both are logically valid but mutually exclusive positions.

Final Answer:

If either I or II is strong.

question:
In the question, a statement is given, followed by two arguments, I and II. You have to consider the statement to be true even it seems to be at variance from commonly known facts. You have to decide which of the given arguments, if any, is a strong argument.

Statement—Should there be a complete ban on registration of new vehicles in the big cities in India?

Arguments—

I. Yes, this is the only way to reduce air pollution and traffic congestion significantly in the big cities.

II. No, Govt. cannot put such restrictions as people can buy new vehicles as and when they need and can afford.
option_1: if only argument I is strong
option_2: if only argument II is strong
option_3: if either I or II is strong
option_4: if both I & II are strong.
solution:
Argument I:

Yes, this is the only way to reduce air pollution and traffic congestion significantly.

  • While this seems reasonable, it’s an extreme measure that may not be practical or enforceable.
  • There could be other ways to reduce pollution and congestion without a complete ban.

Argument II:

No, Govt. cannot put such restrictions as people can buy new vehicles as and when they need and can afford.

  • This argument is strong because it highlights individual rights and economic freedom.
  • A complete ban could disrupt people’s freedom of choice and affect the automobile industry and economy.

Final Answer:

If only argument II is strong.

question:
In the question, a statement is given, followed by two arguments, I and II. You have to consider the statement to be true even it seems to be at variance from commonly known facts. You have to decide which of the given arguments, if any, is a strong argument.

Statement—Should there be no entertainment tax levied by the Govt. on the movie shows in India?

Arguments—

I. No, the Govt. must levy entertainment tax on movie shows.

II. Yes, the common people should not be taxed for movie shows.
option_1: if only argument I is strong
option_2: if only argument II is strong
option_3: if either I or II is strong
option_4: if both I & II are strong.
solution:
Argument I:

No, the Government must levy entertainment tax on movie shows.

  • This is a strong argument because entertainment tax generates revenue for the government, which can fund public services and infrastructure.
  • Removing this tax might reduce government income significantly.

Argument II:

Yes, the common people should not be taxed for movie shows.

  • This is a weak argument because entertainment tax is a common and accepted form of indirect tax.
  • Also, it targets luxury or non-essential services, and people have a choice whether to spend on entertainment or not.

Final Answer:

If only argument I is strong.

question:
In the question, a statement is given, followed by two arguments, I and II. You have to consider the statement to be true even it seems to be at variance from commonly known facts. You have to decide which of the given arguments, if any, is a strong argument.

Statement—Should there be a complete ban on use of pesticides for maintaining fruit growing plants and trees?

Arguments—

I. No, all these plants and trees will get destroyed by the attacks of the pests causing severe financial loss to the farmers.

II. Yes, the hazardous chemicals used in the pesticides find their way into the fruits causing serious health hazard to all those who consume these fruits.
option_1: if only argument I is strong
option_2: if only argument II is strong
option_3: if either I or II is strong
option_4: if both I & II are strong.
solution:
Argument I:

No, plants and trees will be destroyed by pests causing financial loss to farmers.

  • This is a strong argument because pesticides protect crops and prevent losses.

Argument II:

Yes, pesticides cause serious health hazards through chemical residues in fruits.

  • This is also a strong argument due to genuine health concerns.

Why “either I or II”?

  • Both arguments are valid but contradict each other:
    • If you agree with protecting farmers (Argument I), banning pesticides seems unwise.
    • If you prioritize health risks (Argument II), banning pesticides is justified.
  • Since they oppose, only one argument can be considered strong at a time, depending on the viewpoint.

Final Answer:

If either I or II is strong.

question:
In the question, a statement is given, followed by two arguments, I and II. You have to consider the statement to be true even it seems to be at variance from commonly known facts. You have to decide which of the given arguments, if any, is a strong argument.

Statement—Should day to day management of all the government hospitals in the country be handed over to the private companies on operate and maintain basis?

Arguments—

I. Yes, this will considerably improve the quality of services of these hospitals benefiting both the patient and the private companies.

II. No, the poor people may not be able to afford high charges fixed by the private companies and they will be deprived of medical facilities.
option_1: if only argument I is strong
option_2: if only argument II is strong
option_3: if either I or II is strong
option_4: if both I & II are strong.
solution:
Argument I:

Yes, it will improve quality of services benefiting patients and companies.

  • This may not be strong because privatization can prioritize profit over affordable healthcare, possibly neglecting public interest.

Argument II:

No, poor people may not afford high charges and will be deprived of medical care.

  • This is a strong argument because affordability and access to healthcare are critical, especially for the poor who depend on government hospitals.

Final Answer:

If only argument II is strong.

question:
In the question, a statement is given, followed by two arguments, I and II. You have to consider the statement to be true even it seems to be at variance from commonly known facts. You have to decide which of the given arguments, if any, is a strong argument.

Statement—Should gambling be made legally allowed in India?

Arguments—

I. Yes, Government can earn huge amount of money by imposing tax on the amount involved in gambling as people otherwise gamble illegally.

II. No, people belonging to poorer sections of the society will spend their entire earnings on gambling if it is made legal which will lead them and their family to starve.
option_1: if only argument I is strong
option_2: if only argument II is strong
option_3: if either I or II is strong
option_4: if both I & II are strong.
solution:
Argument I:

Yes, Government can earn huge revenue by taxing gambling, which currently happens illegally.

  • This is a strong argument because legalizing gambling can generate significant tax revenue and regulate the industry.

Argument II:

No, poorer people might spend their entire earnings on gambling, leading to poverty and starvation.

  • This is also a strong argument because gambling addiction can harm vulnerable groups and worsen social problems.

Final Answer:

If both I & II are strong.

question:
In the question, a statement is given, followed by two arguments, I and II. You have to consider the statement to be true even it seems to be at variance from commonly known facts. You have to decide which of the given arguments, if any, is a strong argument.

Statement—Should all the villages in India be compulsory given training on use of modern techniques of cultivation?

Arguments—

I. No, the training should be given on selective basis depending upon the land holding and crop pattern.

II. Yes, this is the only way to improve the economic situation in the rural areas.
option_1: if only argument I is strong
option_2: if only argument II is strong
option_3: if either I or II is strong
option_4: if both I & II are strong.
solution:
Argument I:

No, the training should be given on a selective basis depending upon the land holding and crop pattern.

  • Not strong because selective training may leave out marginal farmers who could also benefit from modern techniques. It also risks unequal development.

Argument II:

Yes, this is the only way to improve the economic situation in the rural areas.

  • Strong argument because training all farmers ensures widespread modernization of agriculture, potentially increasing productivity and improving rural livelihoods.

✅ Final Answer:

If only argument II is strong.

(Argument II emphasizes inclusive development through training for all, which supports rural economic upliftment. Argument I, while practical, limits the scope and may miss the broader goal of empowering all farmers equally.)

Note: In argument II, students may think the use of “only” makes the statement extreme and it should be eliminated, but it’s not the case here. The training in modern cultivation is the hour of the need, and it should be imparted to the people in rural area, to avoid incurring losses by them.

question:
In the question, a statement is given, followed by two arguments, I and II. You have to consider the statement to be true even it seems to be at variance from commonly known facts. You have to decide which of the given arguments, if any, is a strong argument.

Statement—Should we scrap the system of formal education beyond graduation?

Arguments—

I. Yes, it will mean taking employment at an early date.

II. No, it will mean lack of depth of knowledge.
option_1: if only argument I is strong
option_2: if only argument II is strong
option_3: if either I or II is strong
option_4: if both I & II are strong.
solution:
Argument I:

Yes, it will mean taking employment at an early date.

  • Not a strong argument. While early employment might be an advantage for some, it does not justify eliminating all higher education, which serves many broader purposes like research, innovation, and advanced knowledge.

Argument II:

No, it will mean lack of depth of knowledge.

  • Strong argument. Higher education contributes significantly to specialization and deeper understanding in fields such as science, medicine, law, and technology.

Final Answer:

If only argument II is strong.

question:
Read the given statement and courses of action carefully and decide which of the courses of action logically follow(s) from the statement.

Statement—With the onset of monsoon all the hospitals are getting increased number of patients due to various epidemics.

Courses of Action—

I. Civic authorities should educate the public the need for observing minimum required hygiene.

II. Civic authorities should make arrangements to equip the hospitals with required medicines and other facilities.
option_1: if only I follows
option_2: if only II follows
option_3: if neither I nor II follows
option_4: if both I and II follow
solution:
Course of Action I:

Civic authorities should educate the public on the need for observing minimum required hygiene.

  • Follows: Preventive measures are crucial during epidemics. Public awareness can help control the spread of diseases.

Course of Action II:

Civic authorities should make arrangements to equip the hospitals with required medicines and other facilities.

  • Follows: Since hospitals are facing increased patient loads, they must be prepared to treat them effectively.

Final Answer:

If both I and II follow

question:
Read the given statement and courses of action carefully and decide which of the courses of action logically follow(s) from the statement.

Statement— More number of students passing SSC examination has resulted into frustration among children for not getting admissions into colleges of their choice.

Courses of Action—

I. Government should permit the colleges to increase the number of seats.

II. Children and their parents should be counselled for being flexibleon the choice of college.
option_1: if only I follows
option_2: if only II follows
option_3: if neither I nor II follows
option_4: if both I and II follow
solution:
Course of Action I:

Government should permit the colleges to increase the number of seats.
Follows — This would directly address the issue of seat shortage and reduce frustration among students.

Course of Action II:

Children and their parents should be counselled for being flexible on the choice of college.
Follows — This would help students cope with the situation better and reduce unrealistic expectations.

Correct Answer:

If both I and II follow

question:
Read the given statement and courses of action carefully and decide which of the courses of action logically follow(s) from the statement.

Statement—With the arrival of monsoon, the condition of roads in the city has begun to deteriorate.

Courses of Action—

I. The Road-Development Authorities should be directed by the State Govt. to take up regular up-keeping of the roads.

II. People should be encouraged to use the pooled/public transport by improving the system to take care of their needs and expectations.
option_1: if only I follows
option_2: if only II follows
option_3: if neither I nor II follows
option_4: if both I and II follow
solution:
Course of Action I follows because maintaining roads is the direct responsibility of the Road Development Authorities, especially during monsoon when damage is expected.

Course of Action II does not logically follow because promoting public transport doesn't solve the core issue of damaged roads. Also, not all areas are accessible by public transport, so it's not a complete solution.

Therefore, only I follows.

question:
Read the given statement and courses of action carefully and decide which of the courses of action logically follow(s) from the statement.

Statement—Many students were caught red handed while using unfair means during the recent university examinations.

Courses of Action—

I. All these students should be debarred from taking university examination in future.

II. The students apprehended while using unfair means should be handed over to the police.
option_1: if only I follows
option_2: if only II follows
option_3: if neither I nor II follows
option_4: if both I and II follow
solution:
Explanation:

  • Course I follows because debarring students caught cheating is a reasonable and common academic action to maintain exam integrity.
  • Course II does not follow because cheating is usually dealt with by the university's disciplinary system, not by involving the police, unless there is a criminal offense involved.

So, only Course I logically follows from the statement.

question:
Read the given statement and courses of action carefully and decide which of the courses of action logically follow(s) from the statement.

Statement—The parents of majority of the students of the local public school have decided to withdraw their wards from the schools to protest against the sharp fee hike.

Courses of Action—

I. The school authority should start a dialogue with the parents and explain to them the circumstances under which the fees had to be hiked.

II. The school authority should immediately scout for new students to fill the vacancy if large number of students are withdrawn from the school.
option_1: if only I follows
option_2: if only II follows
option_3: if neither I nor II follows
option_4: if both I and II follow
solution:
Explanation:

  • Course I logically follows because opening a dialogue with parents is a constructive way to address their concerns and possibly resolve the fee hike issue peacefully.
  • Course II does not logically follow immediately, as the priority should be resolving the dispute rather than rushing to find new students. Scouting for new students is a secondary step after addressing the core issue.

So, only Course I follows.

question:
Read the given statement and courses of action carefully and decide which of the courses of action logically follow(s) from the statement.

Statement—There has been a substantial drop in number of people opting for new telephone connection from the public sector telephone company in the recent months.

Courses of Action—

I. The public sector telephone company should immediately set up a committee to identify the reasons for the drop.

II. The public sector telephone company should offer new schemes with value added services to woo the new clients.
option_1: if only I follows
option_2: if only II follows
option_3: if neither I nor II follows
option_4: if both I and II follow
solution:
Explanation:

  • Course I follows because understanding the reasons behind the drop is essential before taking any corrective steps. Setting up a committee to analyse the problem is a logical first step.
  • Course II also follows because offering attractive schemes and value-added services is a practical way to attract new customers and improve business once the issues are understood.

Therefore, both courses of action logically follow from the statement.

question:
Read the given statement and courses of action carefully and decide which of the courses of action logically follow(s) from the statement.

Statement—Themanagementofthe organization has issued a circular to all its employees stating that each employee must report for duty at 10.00 a.m. sharp and should remain in his/her work place till 5.30 p.m. everyday.

Courses of Action—

I. Themanagementshouldevolvea mechanism to identify such employees whomaynotadheretothetime schedule.

II. All such employees who are found to be failing to maintain time schedule should be summarily suspended.
option_1: if only I follows
option_2: if only II follows
option_3: if neither I nor II follows
option_4: if both I and II follow
solution:
Explanation:

  • The management has issued a strict time schedule.
  • If employees do not follow this schedule, strict consequences like suspension might be considered appropriate.
  • However, course of action I (to evolve a mechanism to identify such employees) is more of a preliminary step and may not necessarily follow logically just from the circular. The circular only states the rule, not the steps to enforce it.

Therefore, only II follows because the statement implies strict adherence and possibly strict punishment for violations.

question:
Read the given statement and courses of action carefully and decide which of the courses of action logically follow(s) from the statement.

Statement—Despiteconsistenteconomic growth, our country has not been able to eradicate poverty.

Courses of Action—

I. The Government should focus their attention towards the below poverty line strata of society.

II. People in the high income group should volunteer and contributeto the Government’s plan of poverty eradication.
option_1: if only I follows
option_2: if only II follows
option_3: if neither I nor II follows
option_4: if both I and II follow
solution:
Explanation:

  • Course of Action I is logical because the government focusing on below poverty line (BPL) people directly targets the problem of poverty, which still exists despite economic growth.
  • Course of Action II also follows because engaging high-income groups to contribute or volunteer can complement government efforts, creating a combined social responsibility approach to eradicate poverty.

Thus, both actions together form a comprehensive strategy — government focus plus social contribution — to address poverty effectively.

question:
A statement is given followed by two assumptions numbered I and II. You have to assume everything in the statement to be true and decide which of the given assumptions is/are implicit in the statement.

Statement—

An advertisement of a Bank “Want to open a bank account! Just dial our ‘room service’ and we will come at your doorsteps.”

Assumptions—

I. There is a section of people who require such service at their home.

II. Now a days banking has become very competitive.
option_1: Only assumption II is implicit
option_2: Only assumption I is implicit
option_3: Both assumptions I and II are implicit
option_4: Neither assumption I nor II is implicit
solution:
Is assumption I implicit?

Yes, definitely. The bank wouldn’t advertise doorstep service unless it believes some people want or need this convenience.

Is assumption II implicit?

The ad offering an innovative service (doorstep account opening) may imply that banks are competing to attract customers, hence they provide unique services. The bank’s effort to attract customers through special services suggests competition in the banking sector.

Conclusion:

Both assumptions I and II are implicit.

question:
A statement is given followed by two assumptions numbered I and II. You have to assume everything in the statement to be true and decide which of the given assumptions is/are implicit in the statement.

Statement—Unemployedallowance should be given to all unemployed youths above 18 years of age.

Assumptions—

I. There are unemployed youths in India who need monetary support.

II. The government has sufficient funds to provide allowance to all unemployed youth.
option_1: Only assumption I is implicit
option_2: Only assumption II is implicit
option_3: Both assumptions I and II are implicit
option_4: Neither assumption I nor II is implicit
solution:
Is assumption I implicit?

Yes, clearly. The statement suggests giving allowance to unemployed youths, which implies that such youths exist and need financial help.

Is assumption II implicit?

No, the statement says what should be done, but it does not imply that the government currently has sufficient funds. The statement is a suggestion or demand, not a statement about financial feasibility.

Conclusion:

Only assumption I is implicit.

question:
A statement is given followed by two assumptions numbered I and II. You have to assume everything in the statement to be true and decide which of the given assumptions is/are implicit in the statement.

Statement—The railway authorities have decided to increase the freight charges by 10 per cent in view of the possibility of incurring losses in the current financial year.

Assumptions—

I. The volume of freight during the remaining period may remain same.

II. The amount so obtained may set off a part or total of the estimated deficit.
option_1: Only assumption I is implicit
option_2: Only assumption II is implicit
option_3: Both assumptions I and II are implicit
option_4: Neither assumption I nor II is implicit
solution:
• Assumption II: The railway authorities are increasing freight charges to recover losses, so they clearly assume that the extra money obtained from the hike will help cover part or all of the deficit. This assumption is directly connected to the decision.
  • Assumption I: The volume of freight may or may not remain the same. The statement does not say or imply that the volume will remain the same. The authorities might be increasing charges regardless of expected changes in volume, so this assumption is not necessarily implicit.

Hence, only assumption II is implicit.

question:
A statement is given followed by two assumptions numbered I and II. You have to assume everything in the statement to be true and decide which of the given assumptions is/are implicit in the statement.

Statement—The police in India have to cope with tremendous stress and strain, while maintaining security and order.

Assumptions—

I. In other countries the police do not have to undergo stress and strain while doing their duties.

II. The police are expected to do their duties without stress and strain.
option_1: Only assumption I is implicit
option_2: Only assumption II is implicit
option_3: Both assumptions I and II are implicit
option_4: Neither assumption I nor II is implicit
solution:
Explanation:

  • Assumption I says: "In other countries the police do not have to undergo stress and strain while doing their duties."
    The statement only talks about police in India facing stress and strain. It does not imply or assume anything about police in other countries. So, assumption I is not implicit.
  • Assumption II says: "The police are expected to do their duties without stress and strain."
    The statement says police face tremendous stress and strain while doing their duties; it does not say or assume that police are expected to work without stress. So, assumption II is not implicit.

Therefore, neither I nor II is implicit.

question:
A statement is given followed by two assumptions numbered I and II. You have to assume everything in the statement to be true and decide which of the given assumptions is/are implicit in the statement.

Statement— “Best way to solve this problem of workers dissatisfaction is to offer them cash reward. If this type of incentive can solve the problem in CIDCO company than why not here”. A personnel manager tells the Chairman of a company.

Assumptions—

I. The reason for worker’s dissatisfaction in both company was similar.

II. Monetary incentives have universal appeal.
option_1: Only assumption I is implicit
option_2: Only assumption II is implicit
option_3: Both assumptions I and II are implicit
option_4: Neither assumption I nor II is implicit
solution:
Assumptions:

I. The reason for worker’s dissatisfaction in both companies was similar.

  • The manager is suggesting that because it worked in CIDCO, it should work here — implying that the dissatisfaction stems from similar reasons in both companies.
  • This assumption is clearly implicit.

II. Monetary incentives have universal appeal.

  • The argument depends on the idea that cash rewards are effective universally or at least in similar contexts.
  • The personnel manager's reasoning suggests a belief that offering cash reward will work here just as it worked in CIDCO, implying monetary incentives are generally effective (universal appeal in this context).
  • Hence, this assumption is also implicit.

So, both assumptions I and II are implicit because:

  • The similarity in dissatisfaction reasons (I) underlies the comparison.
  • The effectiveness of cash rewards across companies (II) underlies the suggested solution.
